etymologies: Old English tōth (plural tēth), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch tand and German Zahn, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin dent-, Greek odont-

definitions: each of a set of hard, bony enamel-coated structures in the jaws of most vertebrates, used for biting and chewing
shortDefinitions: each of set of hard, bony enamel-coated structures in jaws of most vertebrates

definitions: a hard, pointed structure in invertebrate animals, typically functioning in the mechanical breakdown of food.
shortDefinitions: each of a number of hard, pointed structures in or around mouth of some invertebrates

definitions: genuine force or effectiveness of a body or in a law or agreement

examples.text: the Charter would be fine if it had teeth and could be enforced

shortDefinitions: genuine power or effectiveness of organization

definitions: a projecting part on a tool or other instrument, especially one of a series that function or engage together, such as a cog on a gearwheel or a point on a saw or comb.
shortDefinitions: projecting part on tool or other instrument

definitions: a projecting part on an animal or plant, especially one of a jagged or dentate row on the margin of a leaf or shell.
shortDefinitions: projecting part on animal or plant

definitions: an appetite or liking for a particular thing

examples.text: what a tooth for fruit a monkey has!

shortDefinitions: appetite or liking for particular thing

definitions: roughness given to a surface to allow color or glue to adhere

examples.text: the paper used in copying machines is good as it has tooth and takes ink well

shortDefinitions: roughness given to surface to allow colour or glue
